{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3344897,"name":"","username":"Cardinal_System","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cardinal_system/{size}/212637_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-27T02:29:17.128Z","cooked":"

Hello,

I keep getting the infamous (and very uninformative) “CommandScheduler loop overrun” message in my logs and I am not sure what is causing it. I’ve tried to remove the various elements from our robot, one at a time, but the message continues to show in the log.

For context, I am a Java and PHP programmer specializing in manufacturing and web development. I am writing this code with a student who has no previous programming experience. It’s a difficult collaboration because I have no experience myself with FRC programming.

Can someone please help me to diagnose this issue?

This is our repository: GitHub - frc1831/2024

Thank you!

Can you share the log files? Specifically, there should be a timestamped .dslog file and a matching .dsevents file in C:\Users\Public\Documents\FRC\Log Files\DSLogs

When you get loop overruns the rio log/drive station log should post a message telling you how much time each thing is taking. You can use that to figure out where in your code is taking a long time.

As noted previously, the driver station logs will have a code profiler, it’s very helpful here.

That said, I’m betting your issue is in Spinmotor.java periodic. Changing Spark Max configuration settings (limits, currents, idle mode, etc) is extremely slow by default. These are blocking calls that send data over the can bus, and wait for the spark max to reply with an ok or error. This wait a default timeout of 20ms; one robot code loop time.

In your case, just moving this setIdleMode call to the constructor resolves the problem.

In cases where you would want to change setting based on a condition (eg, a current limiting based on position), you can run motor.setCanTimeout(0) in the constructor to make these configuration calls non-blocking. This makes them as fast as any other code, in exchange for not getting the error/ok value back.
